comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Must have been a fairly new shop. The only Haddens in 1911 were a "Supt. Assurance Coy" and family. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/search/results.jsp?census_...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: There's one in Wexford though: www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Wexford/Wexford... And there was one in Dungarvan in the fifties: snap.waterfordcoco.ie/collections/enewspapers/dungarvan_l...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: We've one in Down, two in Wexford, one in Carlow and one in Tyrone in 1911. What we need is a 1925 census.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
32162360@N00
comment._content: It was a Monday . May the fourth be with you.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: As a large trader, the census isn't the best source here. (One wouldn't expect to find many Dunne's on the today's census alongside a Dunnes Stores premises). Trade directories are the best best. I don't have any Waterford directories to hand, but by 1931 at least Hadden's had two premises in Dungarvan. On Main St and Parnell St. Given that the Main St shop is described as a Millners it's likely this is the Parnell St shop. (EDIT - Surely Main St and Parnell St in Dungarvan are the same thing? Will leave it to someone with more local knowledge to sort this one)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The nli record for this photo is labelled Messrs Haddon & Co.(Drapers), interior of shop, rather than Hadden. No useful looking Haddons in the 1911 census, either, though.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: (Waterford Museum has some nice Dungarvan photos of Hadden's and Keohan's next door).

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: It's not the dungarvan shop, anyway. There's not enough wall beside the window to match the view we can see through the shop in the image above.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I think we are looking through the shop, from front to back, and the window we see is at the back of the shop.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02/] It's probably the upper floor in which case it could be the Dungarvan shop (Shaws) looking from the back of the shop towards the front. The window looks the same proportion as the Dungarvan street view image. The parapet on that building could hide a series of pitched roofs with valley gutters (which could also explain the leaky roof!)

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I'd have assumed the opposite. The roof looks like a warehouse extension tacked onto the back of the shop and the bit at the end looks far more solid and is full of stuff on display as opposed to big piles of boxes.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Good point. That makes Dungarvan look a lot more plausible. That would also explain why there's a chimney pipe coming up through the floor.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] but your theory of the warehouse extension is borne out by the aerial photo here

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] although they've obviously re-roofed it in the interim! maps.google.ie/maps?q=dungarvan&hl=en&ll=52.08816...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Probably on account of the shoes getting soggy.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I am almost certain that there was a Haddons shop in Waterford up to quite recently.  Unfortunately the real boss who would know Waterford better than I is out and about so I cannot check.  It is indeed a cornucopia NLI and K shoes were still on the go up to a few years ago if they are not still there.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The only one online seems to be Dungarvan: locdat.waterfordcountylibrary.ie/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I have just got the word from an aged Waterfordian that there was never such an institution in the city.

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content: Nice to see an interior of the stores as we are use to seeing mostly the external shots of buildings.

comment.author: 39750415@N04
comment._content: Excellent

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Incidentally, the only reason I'm discounting Wexford and Carlow is because pretty much all the Poole collection seems to be in Waterford. The roofs of the other two are don't match the picture now but that doesn't prove anything much about what they were like 90 years ago.

comment._content: Sharpener

comment._content: There was an Alderman Hadden in Wexford in 1900 Disgraceful Condition of Wexford Streets (Warning: contains the word 'humbugged')

comment.author: 88162413@N06
comment._content: Lovely one!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I find this one particularly interesting, as my great-great-grandfather ran a draper's shop in Plymouth, and I imagine it would have looked something like this one. (Although under two of his sons it become rather more grand. Warning - contains rhymes worthy of [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] ).

comment.author: 33546386@N03
comment._content: wooow Excellent in one word

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Spank you, John Thooner!

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: If clock is working the sun would be in SSW to SW at 3pm. Intensity of sunlight would suggest window facing south..ish. 'Shaws' Dungarvan shop front faces north. Therefore my guess is that this photo was taken on first floor of annex building to rear of Dungarvan shop facing south. Microsoft has clearer satellite image of what may be these same premises showing what also may be the above mentioned leaky valley. Slatework tone line suggests building extended since. Tis all a maybe. binged.it/ZnOhIw "Whenever the weather is wet ,whenever the weather is fine, whatever the weather the best for leather is Nugget the perfect shine".

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Its a pencil TOPPER

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] You never know with older photos. The long exposure times make any window viewed from inside look like the atom's just been split outside. The light through the skylight, for instance, suggests that we're looking north.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] yes, topper! (is that a Galway thing?)

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Wait a minute. Haven't we seen this before?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Absolutely morto here! Knew it'd happen eventually, but still very embarrassing - mea culpa. That was the 4th photo I uploaded before we launched on the Commons back in June 2011. I did the whole month of May in the space of a few hours for our Year in the Life project. What interests me is the complete lack of comments back then as we were establishing ourselves. The same photo yesterday - 42 really useful comments!!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:

The huge number of comments these days is only proof of your excellence.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 30369211@N00

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] and the quoins of the original building are still visible to the right of the rainwater pipe on the right hand side of the Shaw's facade.
